point.text: Lo! Forsooth! You wander hither and yon, yet wither wil thy wanderings take thee?

response.text: From forth the fatal loins of these two foes; A pair of star cross'd lover take their life.
'Tis now struck twelve; get thee to bed, Horatio.
All the world is a stage, and them men and women merely players.

point.text: But soft! What light through yonder window breaks? It is the east, and Juliet is the sun!

response.text: Arise, fair sun, and kill the envious moon!
Thou dost o'er count me of my father's house!

point.text: Whether 'tis nobler in the mind to suffer the slings and arrow of outrageous fortune; Or, by opposing them, end them?

response.text: O, what a rogue and peasant slave am I! Is it not so monstrous to trap this player here?
To die; to sleep, no More; and by a sleep to say we end the thousand natural shocks that flesh is heir to.

point.text: Life's but a walking shadow; a poor player that struts and frets his hour upon the stage, and then is heard no more.

response.text: To the last syllable of recorded time; and all our yesterdays have lighted fools the way to dusty death.
It is a tale told by an idiot, full of sound and fury, signifying nothing.
